text: Here is a demo, I didn't really tried deploying this, but I suppose it should work. I think what you need to do is insert the navigator to the right children of the parsed HTML node.

text: it's in here: <https://github.com/fonsp/Pluto.jl/blob/d5b8c7763ed3d72edb0f7a8887b216aa49be414f/frontend/common/OfflineHTMLExport.js#L3>

elements.text: it's in here:

text: i wouldn't recommend parsing the html (as that tends to be messy). since the output template is pretty simple (see <https://github.com/fonsp/Pluto.jl/blob/d5b8c7763ed3d72edb0f7a8887b216aa49be414f/frontend/common/OfflineHTMLExport.js#L46|this line>) you should be fine just inserting stuff right after `<body>` (using whatever language you prefer, or even just good 'ol find+replace over multiple files)

<https://github.com/fonsp/PlutoUtils.jl/blob/1109c9dd77160437f3381dd30dfc9ff47182207c/src/Export.jl#L137>

text: thing is that the code from PlutoUtils isn't generating static html, just reading the `editor.html` file and adding some js values which Pluto will then use when it inits. but with static html, Pluto _isn't_ going to init.

didn't play nice for some reason, but this shows that it's possible in theory to get access to the DOM content in julia:
